div.p: Very many thanks for your excellent Sermon which I have read with great pleasure. It is just that union of Religion & good sense which a Sermon should be, with that practical application to the minds of the hearers which must assure their conviction. I am particularly pleased with your rebuke of that morbid sentiment— a pity (for to religion you have clearly shown it has no claims) which puts more for the criminal than his victim, & of the extension of this feeling to the class furnishing our juniors leading to that confounding of justice, & wilful lying which you have so admirably pointed out.
This [illeg] affair like that of the Criminal will I have no doubt bring good out of evil as all history & experience for men is the constant method of Providence in the government of the world.
I am | my dear Sir | yours very truly | W. Spence
